instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: Customer brought in an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that would not boot. He tried to reinstall MacOS Sierra, and he ran into this issue. We tried to boot off several external boot drives, and we got the same issue. Would starting with <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> be a good idea in this case or no? Just wanna start in the right place before doing anything dumb.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: Also, every other chime this thing doesn't display it stays black. It has no image when that happens.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: Ok when you resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> do you pull it and apply new solder or do you just retouch the joints?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: Touched up edges on chip and it works! Thanks for the help Duke! Bad thing for customer is his battery is also screwed, but that's an easy fix.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: I just touch up the solder and then give it a reflow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot
threads.message: Ok thats basically what I did I preheated it with flux and then touched up the edges the iron. Works the way it should now so appreciate the help!
